content.description: A good warm-up for newbies.  Can be tricky at the top.
content.location: Start either as for PJ Party, or walk 10 feet right and start as for Sleepwalking at large obvious crack.  Get to top tier, and follow left-diagonal zigzag seam to top.  Easy walk-off.

content.description: Decent beginner's route; one obvious crux, big holds throughout.
content.location: Start at large, obvious crack; move up trending left, to right of bushes.  Continue up, following path of least resistance. *hint: the route might zigzag a bit*

content.description: Never climbed this one; included it for completeness sake.  The route itself is VERY short, there doesn't appear to be much gear, and building an anchor on top is very difficult without long pieces of static line/webbing.
content.protection: Unknown gear.  VERY long static line needed for anchor, to reach allowable trees.
content.location: Starts on top of a large ledge, 30 feet right of Easy Crack.  Start on left side of ledge; follow seam to left of small roof and up to top.  Easy walkoff.

content.description: Hardest route on this face; very balancy and thin on the upper sections (crux).
content.protection: There is not adequate protection to safely lead this route.  Gear anchor at the top.  Can use directional from the bolted anchor, but it needs its own anchor in truth.
content.location: Start in middle of bottom tier in front of tree; follow middle tier straight up, follow top tier between the two thin, vertical seams at top.  Easy walkoff.

content.description: Never climbed this one, included it for completeness sake.
content.protection: There appears to be very little protection, and an anchor on top is VERY difficult if not impossible without the use of long static line to reach allowable trees.
content.location: Starts on the large ledge 30 feet right of Easy Crack.  Start in middle of ledge; follow thin face and discontinuous seam up through small roof, follow right-diagonal seam to second small roof, escape right and up to top.  Easy walkoff.

content.description: The other route that uses the bolts on top, Night Owl (a.k.a. Bunk Face) is slightly less intimidating than Bunk Arete.  Still solid 5.6 moves, though.
content.protection: Good until you reach the business; then, there is none.  Definite ledge fall.  Bolted anchor at the top.
content.location: Start anywhere for the bottom and middle tiers; upon reaching the final tier, move straight up under leftmost vertical seam at top; reach seam, follow it to top.

content.description: A very good beginner's route.  Also good for a newbie's first lead, as well as good "multipitch" practice.
content.protection: Good pro the entire way.  Gear-only anchor at the top.
content.location: Start at the obvious offwidth crack/dihedral/right-facing corner near the right side of the exposed arete; follow the dihedral up the ledges to the top.  Follow the blue/yellow-blazed access trail to descend.

content.description: I've never climbed this one; including it for completeness sake.  The last of the routes starting on the large ledge.  Right side.
content.protection: Unknown.  Very difficult gear anchor/long static line.
content.location: Starts on large ledge 30 feet right of Easy Crack.  Right side of ledge, about 5 feet from arete.  Climb discontinuous vertical seams to left of small roof, to the top.

content.description: A very heady 5.6, with lots of exposure.  I wish it were longer.
content.protection: Pro is scarce, with definite ledge-fall potential the entire way.  There is a double-bolted anchor at the top.
content.location: Getting off the ground is the easy part.  Climb up the face of the first two "ledges" within a few feet of the arete, then directly up the very exposed arete on the last tier.  Follow the blue/yellow-blazed access trail to descend.

content.description: The easiest route in Peterskill.  Very good for nervous beginners.  Do not top out; stop at the last ledge, at the pine tree (build anchor to come to that point).
content.location: This route starts at a large tree at the furthest right side of the "Gimme Three Steps" ledges.  Follow the easiest path up the right side, stopping at the Pitch Pine above.  Lower off, or scramble (5.2) up one more tier to the top.

content.description:
The only wall visible from the parking lot, and the first to dry after a rain.  Exposed rock, windy routes, shaded and reasonably protected belay area.  A favorite area for guides and groups, as it has one of the few double-bolted anchors in the park and a good mix of route levels in close proximity. 

  Update:   There is a new set of bolts for anchors at the top of the cliff; they are centered over the route "Slumber Party".
